stream_context.summary: Kaze began by detailing a recent 5% performance optimization from fixing the game's culling logic. The main focus was implementing a new, dynamic Star Select screen designed by Biobak, which involved complex challenges in asset loading, positioning, and creating a seamless scrolling background. The stream concluded with Kaze programming a novel and fair respawn system for falling into an oil hazard, using ChatGPT to help generate a key algorithm.

development_findings.summary: Kaze achieved a 3-5% performance improvement by fixing Mario 64's flawed culling code, which used incorrect math and resulted in objects not being culled when they were off-screen.
development_findings.quote: They culled as if the field of view was 45 degrees when in actuality it was 60 degrees and then because they get it wrong they just multiplied it with a random number and added a hundred. So they were culling way too few things.

development_findings.summary: While implementing the new star select, Kaze discovered the text was off-center because the code wasn't using his previously developed, superior kerning system. He updated the function to use his new logic for proper text alignment.
development_findings.quote: I invented kerning, yes. I'm sorry, guys, but I did. I invented kerning.

development_findings.summary: To create a fair respawn system, Kaze used ChatGPT to generate the C code for a complex geometric algorithm that calculates a point's distance from the edge of a triangle, which he then integrated into the game.
development_findings.quote: This is actually something that ChatGPT is insane at. I'll just ask it... You guys have no idea how hard that would have been to program by myself.

development_findings.summary: A new respawn system was created for hazards like oil. It saves the player's last position only if they are a safe distance from the edge of a platform, preventing unfair respawns. This is a more robust solution than simple checkpoints.

Kaze conceived a 'decal Mario' system to add visual effects like oil stains. This involves rendering a second, transparent Mario model over the original, which is a performant way to handle such effects on the N64.
development_findings.quote: Add a decal Mario object that can render in the exact same place as normal Mario and takes a material into transparency. You can fade this decal in/out to render effects over Mario.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is intentionally avoiding complex button combos for camera control to ensure the game feels like a game and not a 'tool' with complicated shortcuts.
development_findings.quote: I want to stick to the one button one output philosophy.

development_findings.summary: Implementing the new star select screen required loading custom models and logic outside of the standard level-loading sequence, presenting a significant technical hurdle.
development_findings.quote: We might have to make a custom segment here. This might end up being a lot more work than I thought it would.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a dark philosophy on why one should not engage with haters, suggesting the ultimate deterrent is the potential for physical violence, not mutual respect for opinions.
context_findings.quote: You know, when you have someone who really hates you, you should not engage with them... that's why you need to put some respect on other humans, because they can murder you. That's the only reason. They don't need to respect their opinions or their views or anything. They're all stupid, but they can murder you.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes using visual scripting tools like Unreal's Blueprints for primary programming is fundamentally flawed, comparing it to eating soup with a shovel and asserting that C++ is superior in every practical way for serious development.
context_findings.quote: You can also drink a full soup with a shovel. If you actually try to make a program in blueprints it's gonna be slower, it's gonna be less performant, it's gonna take a lot longer to program, it's gonna be more limited.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentioned his wife, Zeina, visited him in Germany, indicating their relationship spans international distances.
context_findings.quote: When Zeina was over here I took her to see the seals.

context_findings.summary: Kaze recounted being harassed on Twitter by a fan of an individual named 'Skelinio', who accused Kaze of ruining his life, despite Kaze claiming to have never interacted with him.

key_stories.title: Breathing Life into the Star Select Screen
key_stories.summary: The team replaced the boring, static star select screen with a fully custom, animated one designed by Biobak. Kaze undertook the complex task of implementing it, overcoming challenges with asset loading, text rendering, and seamless background scrolling to create a much more impactful level intro.
key_stories.challenge: The original Mario 64 star select screen was static and boring. The team wanted a more dynamic and impressive introduction to levels that matched the new game's quality.
key_stories.process: Biobak designed a new animated star select in Blender. Kaze then had to implement it in-engine, which involved creating a custom method to load the assets, programming a seamless scrolling background with multiple objects, fixing text-centering with his custom kerning code, and fine-tuning the positioning based on Biobak's feedback.
key_stories.outcome: After extensive trial-and-error, Kaze successfully implemented a fully animated star select screen with a scrolling background that flies in from below, creating a polished and mood-setting experience that will surprise players.
key_stories.key_quote: Imagine you come from Mario 64 and you're all innocent you think it's just gonna be a normal game and then you see this... oh that's gonna be so impressive.

key_stories.title: Solving the Unfair Respawn
key_stories.summary: To solve the problem of where to respawn the player after falling into a hazard, Kaze designed and implemented a novel system. It intelligently saves the player's last 'safe' standing position, avoiding the pitfalls of simpler methods and providing a fair, seamless experience without manual checkpoints.
key_stories.challenge: The game needed a death and respawn mechanic for hazards like oil pits, but simple solutions were problematic. Respawning at the 'last location' could place the player on a dangerous edge, and checkpoints didn't fit the level design.
key_stories.process: Kaze devised a system to constantly check if Mario is on a ground triangle and sufficiently far from its edges. If so, the position is stored as a valid respawn point. He used ChatGPT to generate the complex geometric code for edge-distance calculation. He then polished the experience by finding a suitable death animation and programming the camera to focus on Mario without being disorienting.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a sophisticated respawn system. It saves the player's last safe position and uses a custom death animation and camera sequence, resulting in a fair, non-exploitable, and polished player experience without the need for manually placed checkpoints.
key_stories.key_quote: We check the location to be valid every tick and if it's not valid we just don't back it up... this is actually something that chat gpt is insane at i'll just ask it.
